timeline.message:
SQL support for union datasources.

Exposed via the "UNION ALL" operator. This means that there are now two
different implementations of UNION ALL: one at the top level of a query
that works by concatenating subquery results, and one at the table level
that works by creating a UnionDataSource.

The SQL documentation is updated to discuss these two use cases and how
they behave.

Future work could unify these by building support for a native datasource
that represents the union of multiple subqueries. (Today, UnionDataSource
can only represent the union of tables, not subqueries.)

replies.bodyText: You might be right. I have a sneaking suspicion that we'll want to redesign the DruidRel interface at some point. I was thinking we could rethink it when we create a native datasource that represents a union of queries, which would allow us to merge the two UNION ALL implementations in SQL, which would allow a single-SQL-query-to-single-native-query mapping. That would simplify a lot of stuff and would be a good catalyst for rethinking the interface.

timeline.bodyText:
Hi, is there a particular reason firstDruidRel is of DruidRel<?> but secondDruidRel is DruidQueryRel?
Having it DruidQueryRel creates issues with top level UNION ALL when the second rel contains a subquery.
On the same PR, matches(RelOptRuleCall call) in DruidJoinRule.java has both parts typed as DruidRel<?>
I don't know if it's appropriate to discuss findings in closed PR, but as my issue is completely confined with changes specified here, I took the liberty to discuss them.
